newsitem.title: USA: FOCUS-Dow Jones in Microsoft deal.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Dow Jones in Microsoft deal.

text.p: Dow Jones & Co Inc on Tuesday announced an alliance with Microsoft Corp designed to edge the embattled media group into faster growing markets, revamp its dusty image and help appease disgruntled shareholders.

The two companies will work together on building a package of services compatible with standard computer software and the Internet to bring financial information and electronic trading out of specialist environments and into new markets.
"Its a typical (Bill) Gates deal," said analyst Ed Atorino of Oppenheimer and Co.
"He puts up his expertise and systems and Dow Jones puts up the content," Atorino said.

No financial details were given, but Dow Jones said the initiative is part of plans to spend $650 million over four years revamping its financial information services unit Dow Jones Markets unit, which used to be called Telerate.

Dow Jones, whose flagship is the Wall Street Journal, has been attacked by shareholders for its pedestrian stock market performance and failure to grow as fast as arch-rival Reuters Holdings Plc and aggressive newcomer Bloomberg LP.
Some major shareholders say it should sell Dow Jones Markets instead of spending hundreds of millions of dollars on it after letting rivals get ahead in past years.
Analysts say that, if Microsoft really puts its weight behind the alliance, it could be a potent deal that competitors would have to take seriously.
"Once you put Microsoft in the equation it becomes a serious threat to its competitors," Atorino said.
"If Microsoft is serious about it, it could help close the gap to Reuters. It also gives management something to show shareholders."

Dow Jones closed 5/8 lower at $40-3/4 on the New York Stock Exchange, while Reuters' American Depositary Receipts ended 1/2 weaker at $58-1/8 on Nasdaq. Bloomberg is privately owned, although some investors expect an IPO eventually.

Geoffrey Moore, senior vice president of strategic communications at Dow Jones Markets, forecast the global market for financial information services would grow to $8.5 billion by the end of 1999 from $6.5 billion in 1997.
He told Reuters that Dow Jones was planning to get 17.5 percent of that market by 1999, up from 14.5 percent now.

Moore said Dow Jones will build services that offer electronic transaction services in stock, bond, commodity, energy and foreign exchange with Internet-based standards of news and information presentation, historical databases, risk management and advanced analytical tools.
He acknowledged that both Reuters and Bloomberg were ahead in key areas, but said Dow Jones Markets had worked hard to listen to customers and change its culture.

Moore said the buy side -- fund managers and wealthy individuals -- was a relatively untapped market for Dow Jones Markets, but was growing faster than the sell-side of big trading rooms, which account for most revenues now.
"We want to expand into the buy side, which we think will grow faster and where Bloomberg has done well," he said.
"Transactions is a business that Reuters has been a major player in and it is a $1 billion a year revenue business for them."
Microsoft will not be putting up any money for the venture, but will help distribute the products through its sales force whose coverage overlaps that of Dow Jones.

"For Microsoft it is going to be a great way to sell Windows NT and Internet technology into new market places," Matthew Conners, Microsoft marketing manager for financial services told Reuters. "This does not preclude Microsoft from working with other vendors."
Analysts say Dow Jones's plans are ambitious.
"Dow Jones is giving itself four years. This is not a tune up, its an engine overhaul," Atorino said.
((-- New York Newsrom 212 859 1610))
